Fig. 3.14. Drawing of the cuticle of a instar larva. Care was taken to draw every single
cuticular structure of this particular larva. tl-a8 and te (telson) label the segments. Segments
are subdivided at the level of the ventral sensory hair (vh) into a dorsal and a ventral hal?
which exhibit different patterns. Dotsally there is a complex pattem of tiny hairs, with the ex-
cepuon of prothorax which is devoid ol' them. Dorsal hairs of three types occur, which are dis-
tributed in three tltirds according to a well-defined pattern (labelled a. and in ati). 'Die hair
type anteriorly is small and broad, the intermediate is long and thin, and the type pos-
teriorly is broad and larger than the anterior type. Irrespective of the type dorsal hairs are ori-
ented towards posterior within the anterior pan of each segment and towards anterior within
the posterior part. 'hte arrows dorsally point to the level of polarity inversion in each of 13 to a7
segments. Notice that the level of polarity inversion is at the middle of 13 but it becomes dis-
placed to more oral levels in the more posterior segments, until in a8 the orientation of almost
all dorsal hairs is towards anterior. Ventral aetae, denticles, form prominent belts with 
changing arrangement fromsegmentto segment. 'Die muscular attachment sides (apodemes)
are at between the first and the second denticle row of abdominal segments a2-a8. Denticles
are also polarized as indicated in ao. Additionally, in the dorsal half of abdominal segments
there are three long sensory hairs (labelled dh dorsal sensory hair. lh lateral sensory hair and
vh ventral sensory hair). and within dorsal and ventral halves of thoracic segments three long
sensory hairs (dh2, dh/ and lh), two large campaniform sensilla called black dots (lbd and vbd,
lateral and ventral black dots) and Keilin's organs Notice that prothorax has a dorsal
black dot (dbd) instead ofa lateral one. The dorsal half ol` 118 and the entire telson (derived
from a9 and aI0) are rather modified due to the fonnation of t.he terminal organs. eg. anal
plate (ap) and posterior spiracles and to the appearance of sensory cones (dlrc dorsolateral
sensory cone. dorsomedial sensory cone, desc dorsocaudal sensory cone. and caudal
sensory cone). do and ta are t.he dorsal and terminal organ ofthe antenno-maxillary complex.
